For habitable rooms other than kitchens, the glazed areas need not be openable where the opening is not required by Section R310 and a whole-house mechanical ventilation system or a mechanical ventilation system capable of producing 0.35 air changes per hour in the habitable rooms is installed in accordance with Section M1505.
  2. For kitchens, the glazed areas need not be openable where the opening is not required by Section R310 and a local exhaust system is installed in accordance with Section M1505.
  3. The glazed areas need not be installed in rooms where Exception 1 is satisfied and artificial light is provided that is capable of producing an average illumination of 6 footcandles (65 lux) over the area of the room at a height of 30 inches (762 mm) above the floor level.
  4. Use of sunroom and patio covers, as defined in Section R202, shall be permitted for natural ventilation if in excess of 40 percent of the exterior sunroom walls are open, or are enclosed only by insect screening.

diagrams.title: Habitable Space: Light / Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the Residential Code, Habitable Space is a space in a building for living, sleeping, eating or cooking. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, halls, storage or utility spaces and similar areas are not considered habitable spaces.

Natural lighting and ventilation requirements are found in both the Residential and Building Codes. While both codes require 8% / 4% of the room area for light and ventilation, a difference exists regarding light and ventilation requirements from adjoining rooms (10% for Residential Code, vs. 8% for the Building Code.)

diagrams.title: Natural Ventilation Openings Below Grade (IMC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In the Mechanical Code, natural ventilation for areas below grade does not have the advantage of breezes or the direct natural flow of air at the ground level. Therefore, a larger opening of the window well is required to provide the air needed. Where below grade windows are also used as emergency escape openings, window wells shall comply with the more restrictive of natural ventilation or minimum window well sizes for emergency escape windows.

diagrams.title: Lumens and Footcandles
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A footcandle is the measurement of the amount of light that falls on 1 sf of a surface and is dependent on the light source's intensity and the distance the surface being illuminated is from the light source. Lumens are a measurement of the amount of visible light emitted from a light source, in essences the brightness of the light source. The illumination level of a surface (footcandles) equals the Lumens per square foot that land on the surface, i.e. lumens / projected area in sf = footcandles of illumination.

diagrams.title: Lumens and Footcandles - Calculations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A footcandle is the measurement of the amount of light that falls on 1 sf of a surface and is dependent on the light source's intensity and the distance the surface being illuminated is from the light source. Lumens are a measurement of the amount of visible light emitted from a light source, in essences the brightness of the light source. The illumination level of a surface (footcandles) equals the Lumens per square foot that land on the surface, i.e. lumens / projected area in sf = footcandles of illumination.

children.body:
For the purpose of determining light and ventilation requirements, rooms shall be considered to be a portion of an adjoining room where not less than one-half of the area of the common wall is open and unobstructed and provides an opening of not less than one-tenth of the floor area of the interior room and not less than 25 square feet (2.3 m2).
Exception: Openings required for light or ventilation shall be permitted to open into a sunroom with thermal isolation or a patio cover, provided that there is an openable area between the adjoining room and the sunroom or patio cover of not less than one-tenth of the floor area of the interior room and not less than 20 square feet (2 m2). The minimum openable area to the outdoors shall be based on the total floor area being ventilated.

diagrams.title: Habitable Space: Light / Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the Residential Code, Habitable Space is a space in a building for living, sleeping, eating or cooking. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, halls, storage or utility spaces and similar areas are not considered habitable spaces.

Natural lighting and ventilation requirements are found in both the Residential and Building Codes. While both codes require 8% / 4% of the room area for light and ventilation, a difference exists regarding light and ventilation requirements from adjoining rooms (10% for Residential Code, vs. 8% for the Building Code.)

diagrams.title: Adjoining Rooms: Light and Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An interior room may rely on an adjoining room for natural light and ventilation when certain conditions are met. The common wall must be at least 50% open, the opening must be greater than 1/10th of the are of the interior room and not less than 25 sf. The adjoining room may be a sunroom or covered patio >20 sf provided the conditions of the exception are met.

children.body:
Bathrooms, water closet compartments and other similar rooms shall be provided with aggregate glazing area in windows of not less than 3 square feet (0.3 m2), one-half of which shall be openable.
Exception: The glazed areas shall not be required where artificial light and a local exhaust system are provided. The minimum local exhaust rates shall be determined in accordance with Section M1505. Exhaust air from the space shall be exhausted directly to the outdoors.

diagrams.title: Bathroom Light and Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Natural light and ventilation is required in bathrooms and is typically provided by a operable window. Mechanical ventilation of bathrooms is required by the plumbing code by reference to the mechanical code (Table 403.3.2.3) and is typically provided by an exhaust fan. Providing natural light and ventilation may be omitted provided sufficient artificial light and mechanical ventilation, typically and exhaust fan, is provided. The level of artificial light required must provide an average of 10 fc at a plane 30" above the floor. The exhaust fan must be able to provide 50 cfm if intermittent (switched, humidistat, timer controlled) or 20 cfm if continuously operated. The duct from the exhaust fan must expel air directly to the exterior of the building, not attics or crawl or other spaces within the building envelope.

diagrams.title: Bathroom Light and Ventilation - Exception
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Natural light and ventilation is required in bathrooms and is typically provided by a operable window. Mechanical ventilation of bathrooms is required by the plumbing code by reference to the mechanical code (Table 403.3.2.3) and is typically provided by an exhaust fan. Providing natural light and ventilation may be omitted provided sufficient artificial light and mechanical ventilation, typically and exhaust fan, is provided. The level of artificial light required must provide an average of 10 fc at a plane 30" above the floor. The exhaust fan must be able to provide 50 cfm if intermittent (switched, humidistat, timer controlled) or 20 cfm if continuously operated. The duct from the exhaust fan must expel air directly to the exterior of the building, not attics or crawl or other spaces within the building envelope.

children.body: Buildings and dwelling units complying with Section N1102.4.1 shall be provided with mechanical ventilation in accordance with Section M1505, or with other approved means of ventilation.
Outdoor intake and exhaust openings shall be located in accordance with Sections R303.5.1 and R303.5.2.

Mechanical and gravity outdoor air intake openings shall be located not less than 10 feet (3048 mm) from any hazardous or noxious contaminant, such as vents, chimneys, plumbing vents, streets, alleys, parking lots and loading docks.
For the purpose of this section, the exhaust from dwelling unit toilet rooms, bathrooms and kitchens shall not be considered as hazardous or noxious.

Exceptions:
  1. The 10-foot (3048 mm) separation is not required where the intake opening is located 3 feet (914 mm) or greater below the contaminant source.
  2. Vents and chimneys serving fuel-burning appliances shall be terminated in accordance with the applicable provisions of Chapters 18 and 24.
  3. Clothes dryer exhaust ducts shall be terminated in accordance with Section M1502.3.

diagrams.title: Clothes Dryer Exhaust (IRC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Dryer ducts in M1502 play a crucial role in maintaining the safety and efficiency of your clothes dryer system. Dryer ducts prevent accumulation of lint: Proper dryer duct installation and maintenance help in preventing lint build-up, which is a common cause of fires in homes. Also, code requirements help maintain proper airflow. Properly installed and well-maintained dryer ducts ensure adequate airflow, which is essential for efficient dryer operation and reducing energy consumption. In addition, properly installed ductwork helps avoid backdraft and moisture issues. Dryer ducts equipped with backdraft dampers protect your home from moist air returning inside, preventing mold growth and other humidity-related issues.

children.body: Exhaust air shall not be directed onto walkways.

diagrams.title: Residential Exhaust Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Keeping exhaust openings, such as dryer vents or vent stacks, away from operable windows and property lines prevents the recirculation of unwanted odors, gasses and humidity back into the building or a neighboring structure, or passersby on sidewalks or walkways.

children.body: Air exhaust and intake openings that terminate outdoors shall be protected with corrosion-resistant screens, louvers or grilles having an opening size of not less than 1/4 inch (6 mm) and a maximum opening size of 1/2 inch (13 mm), in any dimension. Openings shall be protected against local weather conditions. Outdoor air exhaust and intake openings shall meet the provisions for exterior wall opening protectives in accordance with this code.

diagrams.title: Residential Exhaust Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Keeping exhaust openings, such as dryer vents or vent stacks, away from operable windows and property lines prevents the recirculation of unwanted odors, gasses and humidity back into the building or a neighboring structure, or passersby on sidewalks or walkways.

children.body:
Interior stairways shall be provided with an artificial light source to illuminate the landings and treads. The light source shall be capable of illuminating treads and landings to levels of not less than 1 footcandle (11 lux) as measured at the center of treads and landings. There shall be a wall switch at each floor level to control the light source where the stairway has six or more risers.
Exception: A switch is not required where remote, central or automatic control of lighting is provided.

diagrams.title: Interior Stair Illumination (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A foot-candle (fc) is a unit of illuminance, representing the amount of light that falls onto a surface. It is defined as one lumen per square foot. To visualize what one foot-candle of illuminance looks like, consider the following description:

Imagine a single candle lit in a completely dark room. If you were to measure the light falling on a one-square-foot surface situated one foot away from the candle (in direct line with the flame and without any obstructions), that would be approximately equivalent to one foot-candle of illuminance.

In practical terms, this is a rather low level of light, akin to the soft, dim light you might experience in a room illuminated only by candlelight. It's more than enough to make out shapes and some details, but it's much dimmer than the lighting levels we're used to in well-lit indoor spaces. To put it into perspective, a typical home living room in the evening with artificial light might range from 10 to 50 foot-candles, whereas an office lighting is typically brighter, often around 30 to 50 foot-candles.

children.body: Exterior stairways shall be provided with an artificial light source located at the top landing of the stairway. Exterior stairways providing access to a basement from the outdoor grade level shall be provided with an artificial light source located at the bottom landing of the stairway.

diagrams.title: Exterior Stair Illumination (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways require an illumination source to be used safely. Stairways to a basement would be those meeting the rise/run and other requirements of the stairway. Illumination would not be required at stairs covered by hinged bulkhead doors, where the height from the basement finished floor level to grade adjacent to the stairway is not more than 8 feet, per Section R311.7.10.2.

children.body:
Required glazed openings shall open directly onto a street or public alley, or a yard or court located on the same lot as the building.

Exceptions:
  1. Required glazed openings that face into a roofed porch where the porch abuts a street, yard or court and the longer side of the porch is not less than 65 percent unobstructed and the ceiling height is not less than 7 feet (2134 mm).
  2. Eave projections shall not be considered as obstructing the clear open space of a yard or court.
  3. Required glazed openings that face into the area under a deck, balcony, bay or floor cantilever where a clear vertical space not less than 36 inches (914 mm) in height is provided.

Required glazed openings shall be permitted to open into sunroom additions or patio covers that abut a street, yard or court if in excess of 40 percent of the exterior sunroom walls are open, or are enclosed only by insect screening, and the ceiling height of the sunroom is not less than 7 feet (2134 mm).

Where the winter design temperature in Table R301.2 is below 60°F (16°C), every dwelling unit shall be provided with heating facilities capable of maintaining a room temperature of not less than 68°F (20°C) at a point 3 feet (914 mm) above the floor and 2 feet (610 mm) from exterior walls in habitable rooms at the design temperature. The installation of one or more portable space heaters shall not be used to achieve compliance with this section.

diagrams.title: Heating Req:  Bldg. vs. Res. Code
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The definition for Habitable Spaces, says that toilet rooms are not included in the definition of habitable space. However, the 2012 Tennessee Property Maintenance Code, as an example, states that heating facilities are required in habitable rooms, bathrooms and toilet rooms. Care should be taken when excluding heating from rooms, including consideration of possible freezing of plumbing fixtures or possible future conversion to a habitable space. It appears possible to conform to the letter of the Residential Code while also not conforming to the Property Maintenance Code.

children.body:
Habitable rooms shall have a floor area of not less than 70 square feet (6.5 m2).
Exception: Kitchens.

diagrams.title: Min. Area and Dimensions (Residential)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code ensures that adequate room is provided in habitable rooms and spaces. Section 304.1 calls for a minimum floor area of 70 sf in habitable rooms. To ensure that no habitable room dimension is too small section 304.2 calls for minimum room dimension of 7' in any horizontal dimension. The minimum habitable room dimension and area requirements do not apply to kitchens. The minimum means of egress width for hallways in residences is 36".

diagrams.title: Dwelling Minimum Facilities
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Inside a dwelling unit a kitchen area and toilet facilities must be provided. Toilet facilities must contain at least a water closet, lavatory and a bathtub or shower. The residential code requires that a kitchen area contains a sink. The electrical code adds the need to provide permanent provisions for food preparation and cooking but does not define the minimum requirements for food preparation or cooking.

children.body:
Habitable rooms shall be not less than 7 feet (2134 mm) in any horizontal dimension.
Exception: Kitchens.

Portions of a room with a sloping ceiling measuring less than 5 feet (1524 mm) or a furred ceiling measuring less than 7 feet (2134 mm) from the finished floor to the finished ceiling shall not be considered as contributing to the minimum required habitable area for that room.
children.displayTitle: R304.3 Height Effect on Room Area

diagrams.title: Smoke Alarms at Ceilings of Different Heights
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where the ceiling of a bedroom is 24" or more above the ceiling of the hallway serving the bedroom a smoke alarm is required both in the bedroom and in the hallway adjacent to the bedroom entry. Where a bedroom contains a sleeping loft a smoke alarm is required in the immediate vicinity of the sleeping loft.

children.body:
Habitable space, hallways and portions of basements containing these spaces shall have a ceiling height of not less than 7 feet (2134 mm). Bathrooms, toilet rooms and laundry rooms shall have a ceiling height of not less than 6 feet 8 inches (2032 mm). Existing basements being converted to habitable space shall have a ceiling height of not less than 6 feet 8 inches (2032 mm).

Exceptions:
  1. For rooms with sloped ceilings, the required floor area of the room shall have a ceiling height of not less than 5 feet (1524 mm) and not less than 50 percent of the required floor area shall have a ceiling height of not less than 7 feet (2134 mm).
  2. The ceiling height above bathroom and toilet room fixtures shall be such that the fixture is capable of being used for its intended purpose. A shower or tub equipped with a showerhead shall have a ceiling height of not less than 6 feet 8 inches (2032 mm) above an area of not less than 30 inches (762 mm) by 30 inches (762 mm) at the showerhead.
  3. Beams, girders, ducts or other obstructions in basements containing habitable space shall be permitted to project to within 6 feet 4 inches (1931 mm) of the finished floor.
  4. Beams and girders spaced apart not less than 36 inches (914 mm) in clear finished width shall project not more than 78 inches (1981 mm) from the finished floor.

diagrams.title: Electrical Panel - Work Space Height
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Electrical panels shall be provided with a clear work space of 36" by 30" minimum from the floor up to a height of 6'-6". However, In existing dwelling units where the electrical service panel is less than 200 amperes, the height of the working space is allowed to be less than 6'-6".

diagrams.title: Clothes Dryer Exhaust (IRC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Dryer ducts in M1502 play a crucial role in maintaining the safety and efficiency of your clothes dryer system. Dryer ducts prevent accumulation of lint: Proper dryer duct installation and maintenance help in preventing lint build-up, which is a common cause of fires in homes. Also, code requirements help maintain proper airflow. Properly installed and well-maintained dryer ducts ensure adequate airflow, which is essential for efficient dryer operation and reducing energy consumption. In addition, properly installed ductwork helps avoid backdraft and moisture issues. Dryer ducts equipped with backdraft dampers protect your home from moist air returning inside, preventing mold growth and other humidity-related issues.

diagrams.title: Res. Fixture Clearances (IPC vs. UPC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fixture clearances shown apply to non-accessible / ADA conditions. Verify with multifamily housing or accessible fixture clearance requirements when fixtures are required to be accessible.

children.body:
Portions of basements that do not contain habitable space or hallways shall have a ceiling height of not less than 6 feet 8 inches (2032 mm).
Exception: At beams, girders, ducts or other obstructions, the ceiling height shall be not less than 6 feet 4 inches (1931 mm) from the finished floor.

diagrams.title: Building Subdrains to Sumps
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Building Subdrain: That portion of a drainage system that does not drain by gravity into the building sewer. Building drainage that can't be naturally discharged to the sewer due to a lack of gravity flow has to be discharged into a suitably covered and vented sump. From this point, the accumulated liquid has to be automatically lifted and conveyed into the building's gravity drainage system or removed through other approved means. This might occur in a building with basement levels where the plumbing fixtures are installed below the level of the building sewer and public sewer or in areas of the building that are lower than the main drainage system, such as a sunken bathtub or a bathroom installed in a basement, making gravity drainage impossible.

Of note, the electrical code does not require a single receptacle supplying a permanently installed sump pump to have ground-fault circuit-interrupter (GFCI) protection if permanently wired in the 2020 code version. Older electrical codes don't require GFCI if the pump is permanently installed, but makes no mention of requiring permanent wiring. Verify the applicable year for your jurisdiction to ensure code compliant electrical installation of sump pumps.

children.body: Every dwelling unit shall be provided with a water closet, lavatory, and a bathtub or shower.

diagrams.title: Dwelling Minimum Facilities
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Inside a dwelling unit a kitchen area and toilet facilities must be provided. Toilet facilities must contain at least a water closet, lavatory and a bathtub or shower. The residential code requires that a kitchen area contains a sink. The electrical code adds the need to provide permanent provisions for food preparation and cooking but does not define the minimum requirements for food preparation or cooking.

children.body: Each dwelling unit shall be provided with a kitchen area and every kitchen area shall be provided with a sink.

diagrams.title: Dwelling Minimum Facilities
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Inside a dwelling unit a kitchen area and toilet facilities must be provided. Toilet facilities must contain at least a water closet, lavatory and a bathtub or shower. The residential code requires that a kitchen area contains a sink. The electrical code adds the need to provide permanent provisions for food preparation and cooking but does not define the minimum requirements for food preparation or cooking.

children.body: Plumbing fixtures shall be connected to a sanitary sewer or to an approved private sewage disposal system.

diagrams.title: Slip Joints
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A slip jointis a mechanical-type joint used primarily on fixture traps. The joint tightness is obtained by compressing a friction-type washer such as rubber, nylon, neoprene, lead or special packing material against the pipe by the tightening of a (slip) nut.

diagrams.title: Common Vent: Connection at Different Levels
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
COMMON VENT. A single pipe venting two trap arms within the same branch interval, either back-to-back or one above the other.

FIXTURE DRAIN. The drain from the trap of a fixture to the junction of that drain with any other drain pipe.

diagrams.title: Cleanouts: Bldg. Sewers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Cleanout: An access opening in the drainage system utilized for the removal of obstructions. Types of cleanouts include a removable plug or cap, and a removable fixture or fixture trap.

diagrams.title: Sink and Dishwasher: Discharge pipe
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A discharge pipe for a sink or dishwasher is a component of the plumbing system that carries wastewater away from the appliance to the building's sewer system or septic system. It is designed to transport used water from sinks, dishwashers, and other similar fixtures to the appropriate waste disposal area while preventing sewer gases and odors from entering the building.

The discharge pipe is made from an approved material, such as ABS, copper, or PVC, to ensure compatibility with the waste being carried and compliance with local plumbing codes.

children.body: Plumbing fixtures shall be connected to an approved water supply. Kitchen sinks, lavatories, bathtubs, showers, bidets, laundry tubs and washing machine outlets shall be provided with hot and cold water.

diagrams.title: Fixture Fittings: Hot Water
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The principle of having hot water faucets on the left and cold water faucets on the right is a standardized practice and it is linked with safety and consistency. This guideline reduces confusion and the risk of accidentally using hot water when cold water is intended. It became a standard because majority of the people are right-handed, and would naturally reach for the right side handle when they want cold water.
There is an exception to this rule for shower and tub/shower mixing valves conforming to specific standards, where the flow of hot water corresponds to the markings on the device, instead of the left-hand side. This is a widespread convention and applies to most plumbing installations.

diagrams.title: Common Vent Connection: Same Level
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
COMMON VENT. A single pipe venting two trap arms within the same branch interval, either back-to-back or one above the other.

FIXTURE DRAIN. The drain from the trap of a fixture to the junction of that drain with any other drain pipe.

diagrams.title: Valve Requirements at Sanitary Sumps and Ejectors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Valves for sanitary drainage are required in pumps or ejectors placed in buildings where the discharge of the sanitary drainage cannot rely on gravity flow alone. Specifically, a check valve and a full open valve need to be installed on the discharge side of the check valve in the pump or ejector discharge piping between the pump or ejector and the gravity drainage system. Access to these valves must be provided, and they should be located above the sump cover or accessibly situated outside the sump below grade in an access pit with a removable cover.

children.displayTitle: Section R307 Toilet, Bath and Shower Spaces

children.body: Fixtures shall be spaced in accordance with Figure R307.1, and in accordance with the requirements of Section P2705.1.

diagrams.title: Residential Plumbing Fixtures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Plumbing fixtures require minimum areas in front to provide safe usability and maintenance of the fixture. Some state codes require compliance with plumbing codes, which may be more stringent than shown in this diagram. These clearances should not be confused with the clearances required for disabled access.

diagrams.title: Res. Fixture Clearances (IPC vs. UPC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fixture clearances shown apply to non-accessible / ADA conditions. Verify with multifamily housing or accessible fixture clearance requirements when fixtures are required to be accessible.

children.body: Bathtub and shower floors and walls above bathtubs with installed shower heads and in shower compartments shall be finished with a nonabsorbent surface. Such wall surfaces shall extend to a height of not less than 6 feet (1829 mm) above the floor.

diagrams.title: Shower Receptor Lining (Res. Code)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A shower receptor liner is a waterproofing membrane that protects both the porous shower wall framing and lower floor layers from eventual water permeation and subsequent moldy outbreak.

diagrams.title: Glazing Next to Doors (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Glazing adjacent to doors can become subject to breakage and require safety glazing materials. The requirements shown here are only applicable to those subject to the Residential Code. Building Code Section 2406.4.2 has more stringent requirements for non-residential applications.

diagrams.title: Glazing: Hazardous Locations
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A set of conditions denote a hazardous location for glazing in either fixed or operable panels. These conditions specify that the exposed area of an individual pane must be greater than 9 square feet. The glazing panel is also expected to be positioned in a manner where the bottom edge is less than 18 inches above the floor and the top edge is greater than 36 inches above the floor. Another significant factor requires that one or more walking surfaces are placed within 36 inches, measured horizontally and in a straight line, of the plane of the glazing. The regulation identifies such scenarios as potentially hazardous due to the risk they might pose to the safety of inhabitants or users.

Safety glazing materials, including but not limited to tempered glass, laminated glass, wire glass or rigid plastic, are used in hazardous locations where the potential for human impact can lead to serious injuries.

diagrams.title: Glazing Next to Stairs and Ramps (IRC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Glazing adjacent to stairs and ramps shall be considered to be in a hazardous location and required safety glazing materials. Safety glazing materials, including but not limited to tempered glass, laminated glass, wire glass or rigid plastic, are used in hazardous locations where the potential for human impact can lead to serious injuries.

diagrams.title: Glazing in Guards and Railings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Any glazing used in guard or railing assemblies by definition in section R308.4.4 is in a "hazardous location" regardless of its area or height above the adjacent walking surface and is therefore required to be safety glazing. When the glass is acting as a structural baluster panel a continuous cap rail is required. The cap rail is required to be supported by 3 or more separate glass panels. Less than 3 glass panels may support the cap rail provided the cap rail will remain in place if one of the supporting panels is broken. A continuous cap rail is not required when the supporting glass panels are laminated glass comprised of two or more layers of the same type and thickness of glass.

diagrams.title: Glazing: Wet Surfaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Glazing in walls, enclosures or fences containing or facing hot tubs, spas, whirlpools, saunas, steam rooms, bathtubs, showers and indoor or outdoor swimming pools where the bottom exposed edge of the glazing is less than 60 inches measured vertically above any standing or walking surface shall be considered to be a hazardous location. This shall apply to single glazing and all panes in multiple glazing.

Exception: Glazing that is more than 60 inches (1524 mm), measured horizontally and in a straight line, from the water's edge of a bathtub, hot tub, spa, whirlpool or swimming pool.

children.body:
Except as indicated in Section R308.1.1 each pane of glazing installed in hazardous locations as defined in Section R308.4 shall be provided with a manufacturer's designation specifying who applied the designation, the type of glass and the safety glazing standard with which it complies, and that is visible in the final installation. The designation shall be acid etched, sandblasted, ceramic-fired, laser etched, embossed, or be of a type that once applied cannot be removed without being destroyed. A label shall be permitted in lieu of the manufacturer's designation.

Exceptions:
  1. For other than tempered glass, manufacturer's designations are not required provided that the building official approves the use of a certificate, affidavit or other evidence confirming compliance with this code.
  2. Tempered spandrel glass is permitted to be identified by the manufacturer with a removable paper designation.

diagrams.title: Glazing in Doors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section R308.4 defines all glazing in door panels as being in a hazardous location and applies to both fixed and operable swinging, sliding, and bifold door panels. Glazing in hazardous locations is required to be safety glazing by section R308.1. There are two exceptions where glazing in a door panel is not considered a hazardous location and safety glazing is not required. Exception one is where the glazed opening in a door panel is sufficiently small that a 3" sphere would not pass through it. Exception two is where decorative glazing, such as a leaded stained-glass assembly, is used in a door panel.

children.body: Multipane assemblies having individual panes not exceeding 1 square foot (0.09 m2) in exposed area shall have not less than one pane in the assembly identified in accordance with Section R308.1. Other panes in the assembly shall be labeled "CPSC 16 CFR 1201" or "ANSI Z97.1" as appropriate.

Regular, float, wired or patterned glass in jalousies and louvered windows shall be not less than nominal <sup>3</sup>/<sub>16</sub> inch (5 mm) thick and not more than 48 inches (1219 mm) in length. Exposed glass edges shall be smooth.
Wired glass with wire exposed on longitudinal edges shall not be used in jalousies or louvered windows.

Individual glazed areas, including glass mirrors in hazardous locations such as those indicated as defined in Section R308.4, shall pass the test requirements of Section R308.3.1.

Exceptions:
  1. Louvered windows and jalousies shall comply with Section R308.2.
  2. Mirrors and other glass panels mounted or hung on a surface that provides a continuous backing support.
  3. Glass unit masonry complying with Section R607.

Where required by other sections of the code, glazing shall be tested in accordance with CPSC 16 CFR 1201. Glazing shall comply with the test criteria for Category II unless otherwise indicated in Table R308.3.1(1).
Exception: Glazing not in doors or enclosures for hot tubs, whirlpools, saunas, steam rooms, bathtubs and showers shall be permitted to be tested in accordance with ANSI Z97.1. Glazing shall comply with the test criteria for Class A unless otherwise indicated in Table R308.3.1(2).
The locations specified in Sections R308.4.1 through R308.4.7 shall be considered to be specific hazardous locations for the purposes of glazing.

diagrams.title: Glazing Next to Doors (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Glazing adjacent to doors can become subject to breakage and require safety glazing materials. The requirements shown here are only applicable to those subject to the Residential Code. Building Code Section 2406.4.2 has more stringent requirements for non-residential applications.

The regulation identifies such scenarios as potentially hazardous due to the risk they might pose to the safety of inhabitants or users.

Safety glazing materials, including but not limited to tempered glass, laminated glass, wire glass or rigid plastic, are used in hazardous locations where the potential for human impact can lead to serious injuries.

diagrams.title: Glazing: Wet Surfaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Glazing in walls, enclosures or fences containing or facing hot tubs, spas, whirlpools, saunas, steam rooms, bathtubs, showers and indoor or outdoor swimming pools where the bottom exposed edge of the glazing is less than 60 inches measured vertically above any standing or walking surface shall be considered to be a hazardous location. This shall apply to single glazing and all panes in multiple glazing.

Exception: Glazing that is more than 60 inches (1524 mm), measured horizontally and in a straight line, from the water's edge of a bathtub, hot tub, spa, whirlpool or swimming pool.

children.body:
Glazing in fixed and operable panels of swinging, sliding and bifold doors shall be considered to be a hazardous location.

Exceptions:
  1. Glazed openings of a size through which a 3-inch-diameter (76 mm) sphere is unable to pass.
  2. Decorative glazing.

diagrams.title: Glazing in Doors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section R308.4 defines all glazing in door panels as being in a hazardous location and applies to both fixed and operable swinging, sliding, and bifold door panels. Glazing in hazardous locations is required to be safety glazing by section R308.1. There are two exceptions where glazing in a door panel is not considered a hazardous location and safety glazing is not required. Exception one is where the glazed opening in a door panel is sufficiently small that a 3" sphere would not pass through it. Exception two is where decorative glazing, such as a leaded stained-glass assembly, is used in a door panel.

children.body:
Glazing in an individual fixed or operable panel adjacent to a door shall be considered to be a hazardous location where the bottom exposed edge of the glazing is less than 60 inches (1524 mm) above the floor or walking surface and it meets either of the following conditions:
  1. Where the glazing is within 24 inches (610 mm) of either side of the door in the plane of the door in a closed position.
  2. Where the glazing is on a wall less than 180 degrees (3.14 rad) from the plane of the door in a closed position and within 24 inches (610 mm) of the hinge side of an in-swinging door.
Exceptions:
  1. Decorative glazing.
  2. Where there is an intervening wall or other permanent barrier between the door and the glazing.
  3. Where access through the door is to a closet or storage area 3 feet (914 mm) or less in depth. Glazing in this application shall comply with Section R308.4.3.
  4. Glazing that is adjacent to the fixed panel of patio doors.

diagrams.title: Glazing Next to Doors (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Glazing adjacent to doors can become subject to breakage and require safety glazing materials. The requirements shown here are only applicable to those subject to the Residential Code. Building Code Section 2406.4.2 has more stringent requirements for non-residential applications.

children.body:
Glazing in an individual fixed or operable panel that meets all of the following conditions shall be considered to be a hazardous location:
  1. The exposed area of an individual pane is larger than 9 square feet (0.836 m2).
  2. The bottom edge of the glazing is less than 18 inches (457 mm) above the floor.
  3. The top edge of the glazing is more than 36 inches (914 mm) above the floor.
  4. One or more walking surfaces are within 36 inches (914 mm), measured horizontally and in a straight line, of the glazing.
Exceptions:
  1. Decorative glazing.
  2. Where glazing is adjacent to a walking surface and a horizontal rail is installed 34 to 38 inches (864 to 965 mm) above the walking surface. The rail shall be capable of withstanding a horizontal load of 50 pounds per linear foot (730 N/m) without contacting the glass and have a cross-sectional height of not less than 11/2 inches (38 mm).
  3. Outboard panes in insulating glass units and other multiple glazed panels where the bottom edge of the glass is 25 feet (7620 mm) or more above grade, a roof, walking surfaces or other horizontal [within 45 degrees (0.79 rad) of horizontal] surface adjacent to the glass exterior.

diagrams.title: Glazing: Hazardous Locations
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A set of conditions denote a hazardous location for glazing in either fixed or operable panels. These conditions specify that the exposed area of an individual pane must be greater than 9 square feet. The glazing panel is also expected to be positioned in a manner where the bottom edge is less than 18 inches above the floor and the top edge is greater than 36 inches above the floor. Another significant factor requires that one or more walking surfaces are placed within 36 inches, measured horizontally and in a straight line, of the plane of the glazing. The regulation identifies such scenarios as potentially hazardous due to the risk they might pose to the safety of inhabitants or users.

Safety glazing materials, including but not limited to tempered glass, laminated glass, wire glass or rigid plastic, are used in hazardous locations where the potential for human impact can lead to serious injuries.

children.body: Glazing in guards and railings, including structural baluster panels and nonstructural in-fill panels, regardless of area or height above a walking surface shall be considered to be a hazardous location.

diagrams.title: Glazing in Guards and Railings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Any glazing used in guard or railing assemblies by definition in section R308.4.4 is in a "hazardous location" regardless of its area or height above the adjacent walking surface and is therefore required to be safety glazing. When the glass is acting as a structural baluster panel a continuous cap rail is required. The cap rail is required to be supported by 3 or more separate glass panels. Less than 3 glass panels may support the cap rail provided the cap rail will remain in place if one of the supporting panels is broken. A continuous cap rail is not required when the supporting glass panels are laminated glass comprised of two or more layers of the same type and thickness of glass.

children.displayTitle: R308.4.4 Glazing in Guards and Railings

children.body:
Guards with structural glass baluster panels shall be installed with an attached top rail or handrail. The top rail or handrail shall be supported by not less than three glass baluster panels, or shall be otherwise supported to remain in place should one glass baluster panel fail.
Exception: An attached top rail or handrail is not required where the glass baluster panels are laminated glass with two or more glass plies of equal thickness and of the same glass type.

Glazing in walls, enclosures or fences containing or adjacent to hot tubs, spas, whirlpools, saunas, steam rooms, bathtubs, showers and indoor or outdoor swimming pools where the bottom exposed edge of the glazing is less than 60 inches (1524 mm) measured vertically above any standing or walking surface shall be considered to be a hazardous location. This shall apply to single glazing and each pane in multiple glazing.
Exception: Glazing that is more than 60 inches (1524 mm), measured horizontally, from the water's edge of a bathtub, hot tub, spa, whirlpool or swimming pool or from the edge of a shower, sauna or steam room.

diagrams.title: Glazing: Wet Surfaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Glazing in walls, enclosures or fences containing or facing hot tubs, spas, whirlpools, saunas, steam rooms, bathtubs, showers and indoor or outdoor swimming pools where the bottom exposed edge of the glazing is less than 60 inches measured vertically above any standing or walking surface shall be considered to be a hazardous location. This shall apply to single glazing and all panes in multiple glazing.

Exception: Glazing that is more than 60 inches (1524 mm), measured horizontally and in a straight line, from the water's edge of a bathtub, hot tub, spa, whirlpool or swimming pool.

children.body:
Glazing where the bottom exposed edge of the glazing is less than 36 inches (914 mm) above the plane of the adjacent walking surface of stairways, landings between flights of stairs and ramps shall be considered to be a hazardous location.

Exceptions:
  1. Where glazing is adjacent to a walking surface and a horizontal rail is installed at 34 to 38 inches (864 to 965 mm) above the walking surface. The rail shall be capable of withstanding a horizontal load of 50 pounds per linear foot (730 N/m) without contacting the glass and have a cross-sectional height of not less than 11/2 inches (38 mm).
  2. Glazing 36 inches (914 mm) or more measured horizontally from the walking surface.

diagrams.title: Stairway and Flight of Stairs
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines a flight of stairs as a continuous run of rectangular treads, winders or combination thereof from one landing to another. A stairway is One or more flights of stairs, either exterior or interior, with the necessary landings and platforms connecting them, to form a continuous and uninterrupted passage from one level to another.

Stairways play an integral role in the means of egress, serving as pivotal paths for people to evacuate a building safely during emergencies.

diagrams.title: Residential Ramps
diagrams.descriptionHtml: While not governed by the ADA, ramps built at private use / privately funded single family homes, have minimum requirements in the Residential Code.

diagrams.title: Glazing Next to Stairs and Ramps (IRC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Glazing adjacent to stairs and ramps shall be considered to be in a hazardous location and required safety glazing materials. Safety glazing materials, including but not limited to tempered glass, laminated glass, wire glass or rigid plastic, are used in hazardous locations where the potential for human impact can lead to serious injuries.

children.displayTitle: R308.4.6 Glazing Adjacent to Stairs and Ramps
children.titleText: Glazing Adjacent to Stairs and Ramps

children.body:
Glazing adjacent to the landing at the bottom of a stairway where the glazing is less than 36 inches (914 mm) above the landing and within a 60-inch (1524 mm) horizontal arc less than 180 degrees (3.14 rad) from the bottom tread nosing shall be considered to be a hazardous location. (See Figure R308.4.7.)
Exception: Where the glazing is protected by a guard complying with Section R312 and the plane of the glass is more than 18 inches (457 mm) from the guard.

diagrams.title: Glazing Next to Stairs and Ramps (IRC)
