Safety glazing materials, including but not limited to tempered glass, laminated glass, wire glass or rigid plastic, are used in hazardous locations where the potential for human impact can lead to serious injuries.

children.displayTitle: R308.4.7 Glazing Adjacent to the Bottom Stair Landing
children.titleText: Glazing Adjacent to the Bottom Stair Landing

children.body: Site-built windows shall comply with Section 2404 of the International Building Code.
Skylights and sloped glazing shall comply with the following sections.

diagrams.title: Skylight Curbs
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because wind driven rain can overcome simple flashings on low slope roofs the code requires additional weatherproofing for skylights on low slope roofs. Where the roof slope is less than 3 in 12 the code requires skylights to be mounted on a raised perimeter skylight curb. The top of the curb must be 4 or more inches above the roof.

children.body:
The following terms are defined in Chapter 2:
  • SKYLIGHT, UNIT.
  • SKYLIGHTS AND SLOPED GLAZING.
  • TUBULAR DAYLIGHTING DEVICE (TDD).

Glazing materials shall be limited to the following:
  1. Laminated glass with not less than a 0.015-inch (0.38 mm) polyvinyl butyral interlayer for glass panes 16 square feet (1.5 m2) or less in area located such that the highest point of the glass is not more than 12 feet (3658 mm) above a walking surface; for higher or larger sizes, the interlayer thickness shall be not less than 0.030 inch (0.76 mm).
  2. Fully tempered glass.
  3. Heat-strengthened glass.
  4. Wired glass.
  5. Approved rigid plastics.

For fully tempered or heat-strengthened glass, a broken glass retention screen meeting the requirements of Section R308.6.7 shall be installed below the full area of the glass, except for fully tempered glass that meets Condition 1 or 2 listed in Section R308.6.5.

Where the inboard pane is fully tempered, heat-strengthened or wired glass, a broken glass retention screen meeting the requirements of Section R308.6.7 shall be installed below the full area of the glass, except for Condition 1 or 2 listed in Section R308.6.5. Other panes in the multiple glazing shall be of any type listed in Section R308.6.2.

Screens shall not be required where laminated glass complying with Item 1 of Section R308.6.2 is used as single glazing or the inboard pane in multiple glazing. Screens shall not be required where fully tempered glass is used as single glazing or the inboard pane in multiple glazing and either of the following conditions is met:
  1. The glass area is 16 square feet (1.49 m2) or less; the highest point of glass is not more than 12 feet (3658 mm) above a walking surface; the nominal glass thickness is not more than 3/16 inch (4.8 mm); and for multiple glazing only the other pane or panes are fully tempered, laminated or wired glass.
  2. The glass area is greater than 16 square feet (1.49 m2); the glass is sloped 30 degrees (0.52 rad) or less from vertical; and the highest point of glass is not more than 10 feet (3048 mm) above a walking surface.
Any glazing material is permitted to be installed without screening in the sloped areas of greenhouses, provided that the greenhouse height at the ridge does not exceed 20 feet (6096 mm) above grade.

The screen and its fastenings shall: be capable of supporting twice the weight of the glazing; be firmly and substantially fastened to the framing members; be installed within 4 inches (102 mm) of the glass; and have a mesh opening of not greater than 1 inch by 1 inch (25 mm by 25 mm).

Unit skylights installed in a roof with a pitch of less than three units vertical in 12 units horizontal (25-percent slope) shall be mounted on a curb extending not less than 4 inches (102 mm) above the plane of the roof, unless otherwise specified in the manufacturer's installation instructions.

diagrams.title: Skylight Curbs
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because wind driven rain can overcome simple flashings on low slope roofs the code requires additional weatherproofing for skylights on low slope roofs. Where the roof slope is less than 3 in 12 the code requires skylights to be mounted on a raised perimeter skylight curb. The top of the curb must be 4 or more inches above the roof.

children.body: Unit skylights and tubular daylighting devices shall be tested by an approved independent laboratory, and bear a label identifying manufacturer, performance grade rating and approved inspection agency to indicate compliance with the requirements of AAMA/WDMA/CSA 101/I.S.2/A440.

Structural wind load design pressures for glass-glazed unit skylights different than the size tested in accordance with Section R308.6.9 shall be permitted to be different than the design value of the tested unit where determined in accordance with one of the following comparative analysis methods:
  1. Structural wind load design pressures for glass-glazed unit skylights smaller than the size tested in accordance with Section R308.6.9 shall be permitted to be higher than the design value of the tested unit provided that such higher pressures are determined by accepted engineering analysis. Components of the smaller unit shall be the same as those of the tested unit. Such calculated design pressures shall be validated by an additional test of the glass-glazed unit skylight having the highest allowable design pressure.
  2. In accordance with WDMA I.S.11.
children.displayTitle: R308.6.9.1 Comparative Analysis for Glass-Glazed Unit Skylights
children.titleText: Comparative Analysis for Glass-Glazed Unit Skylights

diagrams.title: Hydrogen Generation: Req. Garage Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
With hydrogen fuel cell cars on the horizon the code is trying to address the special needs associated with the generation of hydrogen and hydrogen refueling safety concerns. Hydrogen is a highly volatile and odorless gas, the accumulation of hydrogen gas is a potentially very dangerous situation. To limit the potential for hydrogen gas accumulation and ignition the code calls for hydrogen generating and refueling operations to be adequately vented. One acceptable method is via natural ventilation. Two conditions must be met to qualify for Natural Ventilation to be acceptable.
. 1. The floor area served is less or equal to 850 sf
. 2. The maximum rate of hydrogen generation is less than 4 cu ft / minute for every 250 sf of floor area.

Natural Ventilation must be provided by two opening within the same exterior wall. The upper opening must be entirely within 12" of the ceiling. The lower opening must be entirely within 12" of the floor. Each opening must have a minimum cross section dimension of 3" and sized such that the net free ventilation area provided is 1/2 sf /1000 cu ft of garage volume served. Actual net free area numbers should be used in the calcs. if available, if not 25% may be used for wood louvers and 75% for metal. Because hydrogen is lighter than air, the code does not allow for ignition sources of equipment or appliances to be located within 12" of the ceiling, to safeguard against igniting any hydrogen that may accumulate at the ceiling.

diagrams.title: Garages of Fire Sprinklered Houses
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When a residence is constructed with a fire sprinkler system in accordance with section P2904 the exterior walls are required to comply with Table R302.1(2). Section R309.5 requires that the garage space is then also constructed with fire sprinklers that are connected to the residence's automatic fire sprinkler system. The sprinkler heads in garages are required to be residential sprinklers or quick response sprinklers that can deliver 0.05 gallons per minute per square foot of garage. Section R309.5 defines that garage doors are not obstructions regarding sprinkler placement.

children.body:
Garage floor surfaces shall be of approved noncombustible material.
The area of floor used for parking of automobiles or other vehicles shall be sloped to facilitate the movement of liquids to an approved drain or toward the main vehicle entry doorway.
Exception: Detached garages that are separated from the dwelling by a minimum distance of 10 feet (3048 mm).

diagrams.title: Garage Floor Surfaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Because vehicles entering garages are often wet due to inclement weather, the code requires any runoff from vehicles brought into the garage to be managed. The designer may choose to direct the runoff towards either the main vehicle entry door or a floor drain. Because vehicles often have hot exhaust systems and engines which could potentially cause a fire, garage floors surfaces are required to be constructed of an approved noncombustible material such as a concrete slab.

children.body:
Carports shall be open on not less than two sides. Carport floor surfaces shall be of approved noncombustible material. Carports not open on two or more sides shall be considered to be a garage and shall comply with the provisions of this section for garages.
The area of floor used for parking of automobiles or other vehicles shall be sloped to facilitate the movement of liquids to a drain or toward the main vehicle entry doorway.
Exception: Asphalt surfaces shall be permitted at ground level in carports.
Garages and carports located in flood hazard areas as established by Table R301.2 shall be constructed in accordance with Section R322.

diagrams.title: Flood: Wet Floodproofing Garages, Crawlspaces
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Flooding of a structure's interior is intended to counteract hydrostatic pressure on the walls, surfaces, and supports of the structure by equalizing interior with exterior water levels during a flood. Inundation also reduces the danger of buoyancy from hydrostatic uplift forces. Wet measures may require alteration of a structure's design and construction, use of flood-resistant materials, adjustment of allowed in only building operation and maintenance procedures, relocation and treatment of equipment and contents, and emergency preparedness for actions that require human intervention.
Source: FEMA Technical Bulletin TB 7-93, fema.gov

diagrams.title: Flood Venting Layout
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Every enclosed area is required to have at least two flood openings on exterior walls. Flood openings should be installed in at least two sides of each enclosed area to decrease the chance that all openings will be blocked by floating debris and to allow for more even filling and drainage of enclosed areas than if openings are installed on only one side. FEMA recommends that openings be distributed around the perimeter of enclosed areas unless there is clear justification for putting all of the openings on only one or two sides, such as in townhouses with limited exterior walls and buildings set into sloping sites. If openings are not distributed around the perimeter, an imbalance in flood loads could result in damage to or collapse of walls.

The illustration shows a foundation plan with multiple enclosures and openings in the perimeter wall of each enclosed area. Note that the number of openings shown is for illustration purposes only; the total number of openings and the adequacy of the net open area of the openings depend on the type of opening and whether air-vent devices or engineered openings are installed.

In some situations, openings in interior walls or partitions are necessary to ensure that floodwater can reach all enclosed areas and minimize unbalanced hydrostatic loads on interior and exterior walls. When openings are used in interior walls, the total number of openings and their net open area should be based on the size of the enclosed area, but openings in interior walls are not counted toward the required total opening requirement based on the exterior measurement of the enclosed area. To maintain safe fire separation, flood openings should not be placed in the wall separating a garage from living spaces and crawlspaces unless devices used as flood openings that are designed to satisfy fire-separation requirements are used.

Source: FEMA Technical Bulletin 1, March 2020 www.fema.gov

children.body: Automatic garage door openers, if provided, shall be listed and labeled in accordance with UL 325.

Private garages shall be protected by fire sprinklers where the garage wall has been designed based on Table R302.1(2), Note a. Sprinklers in garages shall be connected to an automatic sprinkler system that complies with Section P2904. Garage sprinklers shall be residential sprinklers or quick-response sprinklers, designed to provide a density of 0.05 gpm/ft2. Garage doors shall not be considered obstructions with respect to sprinkler placement.

diagrams.title: Garages of Fire Sprinklered Houses
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When a residence is constructed with a fire sprinkler system in accordance with section P2904 the exterior walls are required to comply with Table R302.1(2). Section R309.5 requires that the garage space is then also constructed with fire sprinklers that are connected to the residence's automatic fire sprinkler system. The sprinkler heads in garages are required to be residential sprinklers or quick response sprinklers that can deliver 0.05 gallons per minute per square foot of garage. Section R309.5 defines that garage doors are not obstructions regarding sprinkler placement.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Basements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency. Emergency escape and rescue openings are intended as a direct means of egress or rescue from sleeping rooms and basements when the primary exit is blocked.

diagrams.title: Yards and Courts
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines yards and courts as:

Yard: An open space, other than a court, unobstructed from the ground to the sky, except where specifically provided by this code, on the lot on which a building is situated.

Court:An open, uncovered space, unobstructed to the sky, bounded on three or more sides by exterior building walls or other enclosing devices.

children.displayTitle: Section R310 Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings

children.body:
Habitable spaces located within basements, habitable spaces located in attics and every sleeping room shall have not less than one operable emergency escape and rescue opening. Where basements and attics contain one or more sleeping rooms, emergency egress and rescue openings shall be required in each sleeping room, but shall not be required in adjoining habitable areas of the basement or attic. Emergency escape and rescue openings shall open directly into a public way, or to a yard or court that opens to a public way.

Exceptions:
  1. Habitable basements without sleeping rooms are not required to have emergency escape and rescue openings when they are provided with two remote, code-compliant stairways.
  2. In existing buildings, basements and attics being converted to habitable space without sleeping rooms are not required to have emergency escape and rescue openings.
  3. A yard shall not be required to open directly into a public way where the yard opens to an unobstructed path from the yard to the public way. Such path shall have a width of not less than 36 inches (914 mm).

diagrams.title: Dwelling Additions - Emergency Escape
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency.

diagrams.title: Basement Alterations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An emergency escape and rescue opening is not required where existing basements undergo alterations or repairs, unless a sleeping room is being added to a basement area.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Basements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency. Emergency escape and rescue openings are intended as a direct means of egress or rescue from sleeping rooms and basements when the primary exit is blocked.

children.displayTitle: R310.1 Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings Required
children.titleText: Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings Required

children.body: Emergency escape and rescue openings shall be operational from the inside of the room without the use of keys, tools or special knowledge. Window opening control devices and fall prevention devices complying with ASTM F2090 shall be permitted for use on windows serving as a required emergency escape and rescue opening and shall be not more than 70 inches (178 cm) above the finished floor.

diagrams.title: Window Opening Control Devices
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Window Opening Control Devices are safety devices installed on windows to limit the opening size, helping to prevent accidental falls, particularly for children. These devices are designed to restrict the window opening to a maximum of 4 inches, while still allowing for easy operation of the window for egress purposes if needed.

Window Opening Control Devices must comply with the ASTM F2090 standard, ensuring their quality and effectiveness in preventing accidents related to window falls. They should be operational from inside the room without the use of keys or tools. In emergency situations, these devices can be released to allow the window to fully open without compromising the minimum net clear opening area required for emergency escape and rescue openings.

children.displayTitle: R310.1.1 Operational Constraints and Opening Control Devices
children.titleText: Operational Constraints and Opening Control Devices

children.body: Emergency escape and rescue openings shall have minimum dimensions in accordance with Sections R310.2.1 through R310.2.4.

diagrams.title: Dwelling Additions - Emergency Escape
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency.

diagrams.title: Basement Alterations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An emergency escape and rescue opening is not required where existing basements undergo alterations or repairs, unless a sleeping room is being added to a basement area.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Basements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency. Emergency escape and rescue openings are intended as a direct means of egress or rescue from sleeping rooms and basements when the primary exit is blocked.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Window Wells
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency.

children.displayTitle: R310.2 Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings

children.body:
Emergency escape and rescue openings shall have a net clear opening of not less than 5.7 square feet (0.530 m2).
Exceptions:
  1. Grade floor openings or below grade openings shall have a net clear opening of not less than 5 square feet (0.465 m2)
  2. Existing buildings undergoing alterations or installation of replacement windows shall be permitted to utilize removable sash to achieve the required minimum net clear openings. Such removable sash shall be capable of being removed without the use of a key or tool.

The minimum net clear opening height dimension shall be 24 inches (610 mm). The minimum net clear opening width dimension shall be 20 inches (508 mm). The net clear opening dimensions shall be the result of normal operation of the opening.

Emergency escape and rescue openings shall have the bottom of the clear opening not greater than 44 inches (1118 mm) above the floor.
Exception: The 44-inch (1118 mm) maximum sill height shall be permitted to be measured vertically above a fixed, permanent platform, step or steps whose minimum width shall equal or exceed the operable width of the opening and shall be centered on such opening and which shall comply with Sections R311.7.5.1 and R311.7.5.2. Glazing in windows complying with this exception shall not be subject to the provisions of Section R308.4.6 or R308.4.7.

Emergency escape and rescue openings installed under decks, porches and cantilevers shall be fully openable and provide a path not less than 36 inches (914 mm) in height and 36 inches (914 mm) in width to a yard or court.
children.displayTitle: R310.2.4 Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings Under Decks, Porches and Cantilevers
children.titleText: Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings Under Decks, Porches and Cantilevers

children.body: Where a door is provided as the required emergency escape and rescue opening, it shall be a side-hinged door or a sliding door.
children.displayTitle: R310.3 Emergency Escape and Rescue Doors

children.body: An emergency escape and rescue opening where the bottom of the clear opening is below the adjacent grade shall be provided with an area well in accordance with Sections R310.4.1 through R310.4.4.

The horizontal area of the area well shall be not less than 9 square feet (0.9 m2), with a horizontal projection and width of not less than 36 inches (914 mm). The size of the area well shall allow the emergency escape and rescue opening to be fully opened.
Exception: The ladder or steps required by Section R310.4.2 shall be permitted to encroach not more than 6 inches (152 mm) into the required dimensions of the area well.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Window Wells
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency.

children.body: Area wells with a vertical depth greater than 44 inches (1118 mm) shall be equipped with an approved, permanently affixed ladder or steps. The ladder or steps shall not be obstructed by the emergency escape and rescue opening where the window or door is in the open position. Ladders or steps required by this section shall not be required to comply with Section R311.7.

Ladders and rungs shall have an inside width of not less than 12 inches (305 mm), shall project not less than 3 inches (76 mm) from the wall and shall be spaced not more than 18 inches (457 mm) on center vertically for the full height of the area well.
Steps shall have an inside width of not less than 12 inches (305 mm), a minimum tread depth of 5 inches (127 mm) and a maximum riser height of 18 inches (457 mm) for the full height of the area well.

Area wells shall be designed for proper drainage by connecting to the building's foundation drainage system required by Section R405.1.
Exception: A drainage system for area wells is not required where the foundation is on well-drained soil or sand-gravel mixture soils in accordance with the United Soil Classification System, Group I Soils, as detailed in Table R405.1.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Window Wells
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency.

diagrams.title: Residential Basement Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Basement walls retaining soil are called "Foundation Walls" in the code. A "retaining wall" is defined by the Residential Code as a wall not laterally supported at the top, that resists lateral soil load and other imposed loads, such as a site retaining wall.

children.body: Where bars, grilles, covers, screens or similar devices are placed over emergency escape and rescue openings, bulkhead enclosures or area wells that serve such openings, the minimum net clear opening size shall comply with Sections R310.2 through R310.2.2 and R310.4.1. Such devices shall be releasable or removable from the inside without the use of a key or tool or force greater than that required for the normal operation of the escape and rescue opening.

diagrams.title: Bulkhead Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A bulkhead enclosure provides a secure and weather-resistant exit from the basement to the outside of a building. The stairways serving bulkhead enclosures are not part of the required primary means of escape. The maximum height from the basement finished floor level to the finished ground level adjacent to the stairway must not exceed 8 ft.

children.displayTitle: R310.4.4 Bars, Grilles, Covers and Screens

children.body:
Replacement windows installed in buildings meeting the scope of this code shall be exempt from Sections R310.2 and R310.4.4, provided that the replacement window meets the following conditions:
  1. The replacement window is the manufacturer's largest standard size window that will fit within the existing frame or existing rough opening. The replacement window is of the same operating style as the existing window or a style that provides for an equal or greater window opening area than the existing window.
  2. The replacement window is not part of a change of occupancy.

diagrams.title: Replacement Windows
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Replacement windows are windows that have been developed in a manner that allows a contractor to not have to remove the exterior materials of the home in order to install the window. Typically they are measured to fit in an existing window opening and will only replace the actual window itself.

children.displayTitle: R310.5 Replacement Windows for Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings
children.titleText: Replacement Windows for Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings

children.body:
Where dwelling additions contain sleeping rooms, an emergency escape and rescue opening shall be provided in each new sleeping room. Where dwelling additions have basements, an emergency escape and rescue opening shall be provided in the new habitable basement.

Exceptions:
  1. An emergency escape and rescue opening is not required in a new basement that contains a sleeping room with an emergency escape and rescue opening.
  2. An emergency escape and rescue opening is not required in a new basement where there is an emergency escape and rescue opening in an existing basement that is accessed from the new basement.
  3. An operable window complying with Section 310.7.1 shall be acceptable as an emergency escape and rescue opening.
  4. Habitable basements without sleeping rooms are not required to have emergency escape and rescue openings when they are provided with two remote, code-compliant stairways.

diagrams.title: Dwelling Additions - Emergency Escape
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency.

children.body:
New sleeping rooms created in an existing basement shall be provided with emergency escape and rescue openings in accordance with Section R310.1. Other than new sleeping rooms, where existing basements undergo alterations or repairs, an emergency escape and rescue opening is not required.
Exception: An operable window complying with Section 310.7.1 shall be acceptable as an emergency escape and rescue opening.

diagrams.title: Basement Alterations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An emergency escape and rescue opening is not required where existing basements undergo alterations or repairs, unless a sleeping room is being added to a basement area.

children.displayTitle: R310.7 Alterations or Repairs of Existing Basements
children.titleText: Alterations or Repairs of Existing Basements

children.body:
Where a change of occupancy would require an emergency escape and rescue opening in accordance with Section 310.1, operable windows serving as the emergency escape and rescue opening shall comply with the following:
  1. An existing operable window shall provide a minimum net clear opening of 4 square feet (0.38 m2) with a minimum net clear opening height of 22 inches (559 mm) and a minimum net clear opening width of 20 inches (508 mm).
  2. A replacement window where such window complies with both of the following:
    1. The replacement window meets the size requirements in Item 1.
    2. The replacement window is the manufacturer's largest standard-size window that will fit within the existing frame or existing rough opening. The replacement window shall be permitted to be of the same operating style as the existing window or a style that provides for an equal or greater window opening area than the existing window.
children.displayTitle: R310.7.1 Existing Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings
children.titleText: Existing Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings

diagrams.title: Tread and Landing Slopes
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Interior treads and landings are typically constructed level. In some locations it may be necessary to slope the tread or landing surface to provide for drainage or to address other unique conditions and construction tolerances. Stairway tread and landing walking surfaces may be sloped up to one unit vertical in 48 units horizontal, or 2% maximum.

diagrams.title: Egress Door Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Each dwelling unit is required to have one Egress Door. The door is required to be a hinged door with a clear opening of 32" with the door at 90°. The minimum egress door opening height is 78" from the top of the threshold to the bottom of the head stop. Other doors exit access doors in the dwelling unit are not required to meet the minimum egress door dimensions. All exit and exit access doors in a dwelling are required to have hardware that enables occupants to readily open the door from inside without the use of a key, special knowledge or effort.

diagrams.title: Vertical Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Habitable levels and habitable attic levels that do not have an egress door shall be provided with vertical egress to an exit. Where required, the vertical egress shall be by a ramp in compliance with R311.8 or by a stairway in compliance with R311.7.

diagrams.title: Stairway Landings: Non Square or Rectangle
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The area and dimensions of a landing may be reduced to one quarter of a circle with a radius not less than the width of the stairway served. The center of the circle must be concentric with the center of the walkline at the landing.

children.body: Dwellings shall be provided with a means of egress in accordance with this section. The means of egress shall provide a continuous and unobstructed path of vertical and horizontal egress travel from all portions of the dwelling to the required egress door without requiring travel through a garage. The required egress door shall open directly into a public way or to a yard or court that opens to a public way.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress Pathways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: From any location within a dwelling an unobstructed and continuous path horizontal and vertical path shall be provided to the required egress door. The egress path of travel shall not pass through the garage to reach the required egress door. The required egress door is required to open directly to a public way or to a yard or court that opens to a public way.

children.body: Not less than one egress door shall be provided for each dwelling unit. The egress door shall be side-hinged, and shall provide a clear width of not less than 32 inches (813 mm) where measured between the face of the door and the stop, with the door open 90 degrees (1.57 rad). The clear height of the door opening shall be not less than 78 inches (1981 mm) in height measured from the top of the threshold to the bottom of the stop. Other doors shall not be required to comply with these minimum dimensions. Egress doors shall be readily openable from inside the dwelling without the use of a key or special knowledge or effort.

diagrams.title: Doors: Min. Required Clear Opening Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A door has to be at least 32" minimum clear width to provide enough space for people with mobility impairments or those who use mobility aids (such as wheelchairs, walkers or crutches) to pass through comfortably. Wider door widths are required for Group I-2 when movement of beds is required. Other exceptions also apply in Section 1010.1.1. Door widths should be sufficient to allow safe passage in the clear space between the face of the door to the edge of the door stop.

diagrams.title: Residential Ramps
diagrams.descriptionHtml: While not governed by the ADA, ramps built at private use / privately funded single family homes, have minimum requirements in the Residential Code.

diagrams.title: Egress Door Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Each dwelling unit is required to have one Egress Door. The door is required to be a hinged door with a clear opening of 32" with the door at 90°. The minimum egress door opening height is 78" from the top of the threshold to the bottom of the head stop. Other doors exit access doors in the dwelling unit are not required to meet the minimum egress door dimensions. All exit and exit access doors in a dwelling are required to have hardware that enables occupants to readily open the door from inside without the use of a key, special knowledge or effort.

diagrams.title: Vertical Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Habitable levels and habitable attic levels that do not have an egress door shall be provided with vertical egress to an exit. Where required, the vertical egress shall be by a ramp in compliance with R311.8 or by a stairway in compliance with R311.7.

children.body:
There shall be a landing or floor on each side of each exterior door. The width of each landing shall be not less than the door served. Landings shall have a dimension of not less than 36 inches (914 mm) measured in the direction of travel. The slope at exterior landings shall not exceed 1/4 unit vertical in 12 units horizontal (2 percent).
Exception: Exterior balconies less than 60 square feet (5.6 m2) and only accessed from a door are permitted to have a landing that is less than 36 inches (914 mm) measured in the direction of travel.

diagrams.title: Landings at Balcony Doors: Exception
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Balconies of limited size are not required to have a full depth landing/floor area normally required for an exterior doorway.

children.displayTitle: R311.3 Floors and Landings at Exterior Doors
children.titleText: Floors and Landings at Exterior Doors

children.body:
Landings or finished floors at the required egress door shall not be more than 11/2 inches (38 mm) lower than the top of the threshold.
Exception: The landing or floor on the exterior side shall not be more than 81/4 inches (209.5 mm) below the top of the threshold provided the door does not swing over the landing or the floor.
Where exterior landings or floors serving the required egress door are not at grade, they shall be provided with access to grade by means of a ramp in accordance with Section R311.8 or a stairway in accordance with Section R311.7.
children.displayTitle: R311.3.1 Floor Elevations at the Required Egress Doors
children.titleText: Floor Elevations at the Required Egress Doors

children.body:
Doors other than the required egress door shall be provided with landings or floors not more than 81/4 inches (209.5 mm) below the top of the threshold.
Exception: A landing is not required where a stairway of three or fewer risers, including the top riser from the dwelling to the top tread, is located on the exterior side of the door, provided the door does not swing over the stairway.
children.displayTitle: R311.3.2 Floor Elevations atfor Other Exterior Doors
children.titleText: Floor Elevations atfor Other Exterior Doors

children.body: Storm and screen doors shall be permitted to swing over exterior stairs and landings.

Egress from habitable levels including habitable attics and basements that are not provided with an egress door in accordance with Section R311.2 shall be by a ramp in accordance with Section R311.8 or a stairway in accordance with Section R311.7.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Basements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency. Emergency escape and rescue openings are intended as a direct means of egress or rescue from sleeping rooms and basements when the primary exit is blocked.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress Pathways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: From any location within a dwelling an unobstructed and continuous path horizontal and vertical path shall be provided to the required egress door. The egress path of travel shall not pass through the garage to reach the required egress door. The required egress door is required to open directly to a public way or to a yard or court that opens to a public way.

diagrams.title: Vertical Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Habitable levels and habitable attic levels that do not have an egress door shall be provided with vertical egress to an exit. Where required, the vertical egress shall be by a ramp in compliance with R311.8 or by a stairway in compliance with R311.7.

children.body: Exterior landings, decks, balconies, stairs and similar facilities shall be positively anchored to the primary structure to resist both vertical and lateral forces or shall be designed to be self-supporting. Attachment shall not be accomplished by use of toenails or nails subject to withdrawal.

diagrams.title: Guards:  Connection Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
ASCE 7 requires the 200 pound load to be placed in any direction at any point on the handrail or top rail to produce a maximum load effect. This would mean a load pulling on the rail inward would create a maximum tension on the bottom bolt, but a 200 pound force outward (typically associated with "falling" outward) would put the maximum tension on the top bolt.

However, the Residential Code, in Table R301.5, footnote d, states: "A single concentrated load applied in any direction at any point along the top. For a guard not required to serve as a handrail, the load need not be applied to the top element of the guard in a direction parallel to such element." This language does not seem to appear in ASCE 7 at this time.

Therefore, the designer should consider providing tension resisting hardware on both bolts, or consider an alternate design. Simply relying on the rim board would put the member into cross-grain bending, which has considerably lower strength than the beam itself.

diagrams.title: Landings at Balcony Doors: Exception
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Balconies of limited size are not required to have a full depth landing/floor area normally required for an exterior doorway.

children.displayTitle: R311.5 Landing, Deck, Balcony and Stair Construction and Attachment
children.titleText: Landing, Deck, Balcony and Stair Construction and Attachment

children.body: The width of a hallway shall be not less than 3 feet (914 mm).

diagrams.title: Min. Area and Dimensions (Residential)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code ensures that adequate room is provided in habitable rooms and spaces. Section 304.1 calls for a minimum floor area of 70 sf in habitable rooms. To ensure that no habitable room dimension is too small section 304.2 calls for minimum room dimension of 7' in any horizontal dimension. The minimum habitable room dimension and area requirements do not apply to kitchens. The minimum means of egress width for hallways in residences is 36".

children.body:
Where required by this code or provided, stairways shall comply with this section.

Exceptions:
  1. Stairways not within or serving a building, porch or deck.
  2. Stairways leading to nonhabitable attics.
  3. Stairways leading to crawl spaces.

diagrams.title: Type I Handrail Profile (Res.)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Type I handrails are either circular with a cross section that has an outside diameter between 1-1/4" to 2" maximum. When the handrail is not circular, then it needs to have a perimeter that is between 4" to 6-1/4" maximum with a cross section that is not greater than 2-1/4". The edges of non-circular handrail can have a radius of 0.01" minimum.

diagrams.title: Handrail Continuity - Exception
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Handrail continuity is important for various reasons related to safety, accessibility, and compliance with building regulations. Firstly, a continuous handrail maximizes safety by providing continuous support for individuals navigating staircases and ramps, reducing the risk of slips and falls. This is especially beneficial for individuals who may have mobility issues, such as older adults or individuals with certain disabilities. Newel posts at a turn in the flight with winders, at landings or over the lowest tread are permitted to interrupt the continuity of the handrail. A volute, turnout or starting easing shall be permitted to terminate over the lowest tread as well.

diagrams.title: Handrail Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Handrail continuity is important for various reasons related to safety, accessibility, and compliance with building regulations. Firstly, a continuous handrail maximizes safety by providing continuous support for individuals navigating staircases and ramps, reducing the risk of slips and falls. This is especially beneficial for individuals who may have mobility issues, such as older adults or individuals with certain disabilities. Handrails' continuation without interruption by newel posts or other obstructions, also facilitates quicker and safer evacuation during an emergency.

diagrams.title: Type II Handrail Profile
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A Type 2 handrail is one that is larger than the graspable perimeter of a Type 1 handrail. In this condition, handrails with a perimeter greater than 6-1/4 inches are required to provide a graspable finger recess area on both sides of the profile. The Stair Manufacturers Association funded a study that determined that a pinch grip could provide graspable handrail. This was added to the Residential Code in 2001 and the Building Code for multifamily residential in 2009.

diagrams.title: Stairway Headroom and Vert. Rise (Residential)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways require a minimum amount of headroom height. When placing stairways on a plan, always be sure to check if the stair when viewed in section, with the required rise and run of the treads, won't conflict with the floor above as as person comes up or down the stairs. Ways to fix this in the field can be undesirable aesthetically or expensive.

diagrams.title: Residential Guards
diagrams.descriptionHtml: GUARD. A building component or a system of building components located near the open sides of elevated walking surfaces that minimizes the possibility of a fall from the walking surface to the lower level.

diagrams.title: Winder Treads
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Winder treads are allowed only in one and two-family dwellings in most new construction. Proper width at the narrow end of the winder tread is necessary to prevent an almost vertical condition where the risers for multiple stair are in near vertical alignment. In addition, at the location where the foot would typically land with ones shoulder is nearest the wall (the walkline), a full tread depth is required. In the residential code, the walkline is considered 12" from the side of the stairway at the inner side of the winding stair.

diagrams.title: Glazing Next to Stairs and Ramps (IRC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Glazing adjacent to stairs and ramps shall be considered to be in a hazardous location and required safety glazing materials. Safety glazing materials, including but not limited to tempered glass, laminated glass, wire glass or rigid plastic, are used in hazardous locations where the potential for human impact can lead to serious injuries.

diagrams.title: Handrail Height
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A handrail is required on at least one side of all flights of stairs exceeding 3 risers. Handrail height along flights of stairs is measured from the imaginary plane or planes defined by the stairway's tread nosing. The code calls for handrails to be from 34 to 38 inches in height. Though not specifically noted in the code, handrail height should be consistent along each flight of stairs. The code allows for the rail height to exceed 38" at continuous transitions, typically called "goosenecks", that take place at between flights of stairs, winder treads, and where the handrail transitions from a stair handrail to a guard. Over the lowest tread, the code also allows for the handrail height to be lower than 34" or taller than 38" for a volute, turnout or starting easing.

diagrams.title: Example: Floor Opening - Stairway With Landing
Bulkhead Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A bulkhead enclosure provides a secure and weather-resistant exit from the basement to the outside of a building. The stairways serving bulkhead enclosures are not part of the required primary means of escape. The maximum height from the basement finished floor level to the finished ground level adjacent to the stairway must not exceed 8 ft.

diagrams.title: Stair Walkline
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The location of the walkline at winder treads and landings is defined in the code. The walkline is parallel to the direction of travel. The walkline is located 12" from the inside face of the stair's clear width on the inside side of the turn. Where the stairway is "S" shaped the walkline will change sides of the stairway such that it is always 12" from the inside of the turn.

diagrams.title: Tread and Landing Slopes
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Interior treads and landings are typically constructed level. In some locations it may be necessary to slope the tread or landing surface to provide for drainage or to address other unique conditions and construction tolerances. Stairway tread and landing walking surfaces may be sloped up to one unit vertical in 48 units horizontal, or 2% maximum.

diagrams.title: Stairway Landings: Non Square or Rectangle
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The area and dimensions of a landing may be reduced to one quarter of a circle with a radius not less than the width of the stairway served. The center of the circle must be concentric with the center of the walkline at the landing.

children.body:
Stairways shall not be less than 36 inches (914 mm) in clear width at all points above the permitted handrail height and below the required headroom height. The clear width of stairways at and below the handrail height, including treads and landings, shall not be less than 311/2 inches (800 mm) where a handrail is installed on one side and 27 inches (686 mm) where handrails are provided on both sides.
Exceptions: 
  1. The width of spiral stairways shall be in accordance with Section R311.7.10.1.
  2. The width of existing stairways serving existing unfinished attics or existing unfinished basements being converted to habitable space or replacement stairways within existing dwellings shall not be less than 32 inches (813 mm) in clear width at all points above the permitted handrail height and below the required headroom height. The clear width of stairways at and below the handrail height, including treads and landings, shall not be less than 28 inches (711 mm) where a handrail is installed on one side and 24 inches (610 mm) where handrails are provided on both sides.
  3. Where an incline platform lift or stairway chairlift is installed on a stairway within a dwelling unit, a clear passage width not less than 20 inches (508 mm) shall be provided. If the seat and platform can be folded when not in use, the distance shall be measured from the folded position.

The minimum headroom in all parts of the stairway shall not be less than 6 feet, 8 inches (2032 mm) measured vertically from the sloped line adjoining the tread nosing or from the floor surface of the landing or platform on that portion of the stairway.

Exceptions:
  1. Where the nosing of treads at the side of a flight extend under the edge of a floor opening through which the stair passes, the floor opening shall be allowed to project horizontally into the required headroom a maximum of 43/4 inches (121 mm).
  2. The minimum headroom in all parts of existing stairways serving existing unfinished attics or existing unfinished basements being converted to habitable space or replacement stairs where the pitch or slope cannot be reduced because of existing construction shall be 6 feet, 4 inches (1930mm), measured in accordance with Section R311.7.2.

diagrams.title: Stairway Headroom and Vert. Rise (Residential)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways require a minimum amount of headroom height. When placing stairways on a plan, always be sure to check if the stair when viewed in section, with the required rise and run of the treads, won't conflict with the floor above as as person comes up or down the stairs. Ways to fix this in the field can be undesirable aesthetically or expensive.

children.body: A flight of stairs shall not have a vertical rise greater than 12 feet 7 inches (3835 mm) between floor levels or landings.

diagrams.title: Stairway Headroom and Vert. Rise (Residential)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways require a minimum amount of headroom height. When placing stairways on a plan, always be sure to check if the stair when viewed in section, with the required rise and run of the treads, won't conflict with the floor above as as person comes up or down the stairs. Ways to fix this in the field can be undesirable aesthetically or expensive.

children.body: The walkline across winder treads and landings shall be concentric to the turn and parallel to the direction of travel entering and exiting the turn. The walkline shall be located 12 inches (305 mm) from the inside of the turn. The 12-inch (305 mm) dimension shall be measured from the widest point of the clear stair width at the walking surface. Where winders are adjacent within a flight, the point of the widest clear stair width of the adjacent winders shall be used.

Proper width at the narrow end of the winder tread is necessary to prevent an almost vertical condition where the risers for multiple stair are in near vertical alignment. In addition, at the location where the foot would typically land with ones shoulder is nearest the wall (the walkline), a full tread depth is required. In the residential code, the walkline is considered 12" from the side of the stairway at the inner side of the winding stair.

diagrams.title: Stair Walkline
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The location of the walkline at winder treads and landings is defined in the code. The walkline is parallel to the direction of travel. The walkline is located 12" from the inside face of the stair's clear width on the inside side of the turn. Where the stairway is "S" shaped the walkline will change sides of the stairway such that it is always 12" from the inside of the turn.

children.body: Stair treads and risers shall meet the requirements of this section. For the purposes of this section, dimensions and dimensioned surfaces shall be exclusive of carpets, rugs or runners.

diagrams.title: Stair Riser / Tread Depth, Res. (CT, IN)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stair treads at one and two family dwellings and within Group R-2 units allow for a steeper slope (rise / run) than do stairs in common or public access areas. The requirements are a minimum stair tread length (horizontal component) and maximum stair rise (vertical component). Variations of treads from tread to tread or smaller tread lengths and higher riser heights increase the potential for tripping or falls on stairways.

children.body:
The riser height shall be not more than 81/4 inches (209.5 mm). The riser shall be measured vertically between leading edges of adjacent treads. The greatest riser height within any flight of stairs shall not exceed the smallest by more than 3/8 inch (9.5 mm). Risers shall be vertical or sloped from the underside of the nosing of the tread above at an angle not more than 30 degrees (0.51 rad) from the vertical. Open risers are permitted provided that the opening between treads does not permit the passage of a 4-inch-diameter (102 mm) sphere.
Exceptions:
  1. The maximum riser height of existing stairs serving existing unfinished attics or existing unfinished basements being converted to habitable space or replacement stairs where the pitch or slope cannot be reduced because of existing construction shall be 9 inches (229 mm), measured in accordance with Section R311.7.5.1.
  2. The opening between adjacent treads is not limited on spiral stairways.
  3. The riser height of spiral stairways shall be in accordance with Section R311.7.10.1.

The minimum tread depth shall be 9 inches (229 mm). The tread depth shall be measured horizontally between the vertical planes of the foremost projection of adjacent treads and at a right angle to the tread's leading edge. The greatest tread depth within any flight of stairs shall not exceed the smallest by more than 3/8 inch (9.5 mm).
Exception: The minimum tread depth of existing stairs serving existing unfinished attics or existing unfinished basements being converted to habitable space or replacement stairs within existing dwellings shall be 8 inches (203 mm), measured in accordance with Section R311.7.5.2.

Winder treads shall have a tread depth of not less than 10 inches (254 mm) measured between the vertical planes of the foremost projection of adjacent treads at the intersections with the walkline. Winder treads shall have a tread depth of not less than 6 inches (152 mm) at any point within the clear width of the stair. Within any flight of stairs, the largest winder tread depth at the walkline shall not exceed the smallest winder tread by more than 3/8 inch (9.5 mm). Consistently shaped winders at the walkline shall be allowed within the same flight of stairs as rectangular treads and shall not be required to be within 3/8 inch (9.5 mm) of the rectangular tread depth.
Exception: The tread depth at spiral stairways shall be in accordance with Section R311.7.10.1.

diagrams.title: Stairway and Flight of Stairs
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines a flight of stairs as a continuous run of rectangular treads, winders or combination thereof from one landing to another. A stairway is One or more flights of stairs, either exterior or interior, with the necessary landings and platforms connecting them, to form a continuous and uninterrupted passage from one level to another.

Stairways play an integral role in the means of egress, serving as pivotal paths for people to evacuate a building safely during emergencies.

diagrams.title: Winder Treads
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Winder treads are allowed only in one and two-family dwellings in most new construction. Proper width at the narrow end of the winder tread is necessary to prevent an almost vertical condition where the risers for multiple stair are in near vertical alignment. In addition, at the location where the foot would typically land with ones shoulder is nearest the wall (the walkline), a full tread depth is required. In the residential code, the walkline is considered 12" from the side of the stairway at the inner side of the winding stair.

diagrams.title: Stair Walkline
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The location of the walkline at winder treads and landings is defined in the code. The walkline is parallel to the direction of travel. The walkline is located 12" from the inside face of the stair's clear width on the inside side of the turn. Where the stairway is "S" shaped the walkline will change sides of the stairway such that it is always 12" from the inside of the turn.

children.body:
Nosings at treads, landings and floors of stairways shall have a radius of curvature at the nosing not greater than 9/16 inch (14 mm) or a bevel not greater than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm). A nosing projection not less than 3/4 inch (19 mm) and not more than 11/4 inches (32 mm) shall be provided on stairways. The greatest nosing projection shall not exceed the smallest nosing projection by more than 3/8 inch (9.5 mm) within a stairway.
Exception: A nosing projection is not required where the tread depth is not less than 11 inches (279 mm).
Plastic composite exterior stair treads shall comply with the provisions of this section and Section R507.2.2.
children.displayTitle: R311.7.5.4 Exterior Plastic Composite Stair Treads

children.body:
There shall be a floor or landing at the top and bottom of each stairway. The width perpendicular to the direction of travel shall be not less than the width of the flight served. For landings of shapes other than square or rectangular the depth at the walk line and the total area shall be not less than that of a quarter circle with a radius equal to the required landing width. Where the stairway has a straight run, the depth in the direction of travel shall be not less than 36 inches (914 mm).
Exceptions: 
  1. A floor or landing is not required at the top of an interior flight of stairs, including stairs in an enclosed garage, provided that a door does not swing over the stairs.
  2. The depth in the direction of travel of landings of existing stairs serving existing unfinished attics or basements being converted to habitable space or replacement stairs within existing dwellings shall be at least equal to the stair width but not less than 32 inches (813 mm) where Section R311.7.1, exception 2 is utilized for a reduced stair width.

diagrams.title: Stairway Landings: Non Square or Rectangle
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The area and dimensions of a landing may be reduced to one quarter of a circle with a radius not less than the width of the stairway served. The center of the circle must be concentric with the center of the walkline at the landing.

children.body:
The walking surface of treads and landings of stairways shall be sloped not steeper than 1 unit vertical in 48 units horizontal (2-percent slope).
Exception: Where the surface of a landing is required elsewhere in the code to drain surface water, the walking surface of the landing shall be sloped not steeper than 1 unit vertical in 20 units horizontal (5-percent slope) in the direction of travel.

diagrams.title: Tread and Landing Slopes
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Interior treads and landings are typically constructed level. In some locations it may be necessary to slope the tread or landing surface to provide for drainage or to address other unique conditions and construction tolerances. Stairway tread and landing walking surfaces may be sloped up to one unit vertical in 48 units horizontal, or 2% maximum.

children.body: Handrails shall be provided on not less than one side of each flight of stairs with four or more risers.

When the handrail is not circular, then it needs to have a perimeter that is between 4" to 6-1/4" maximum with a cross section that is not greater than 2-1/4". The edges of non-circular handrail can have a radius of 0.01" minimum.

Handrail height along flights of stairs is measured from the imaginary plane or planes defined by the stairway's tread nosing. The code calls for handrails to be from 34 to 38 inches in height. Over the lowest tread, the code also allows for the handrail height to be lower than 34" or taller than 38" for a volute, turnout or starting easing.

diagrams.title: Ship's Ladders (Residential)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Ship's ladders may not be used as a required means of egress. A ship's ladder may be provided in addition to a compliant required means of egress. There is an exception for spaces such as lofts, mezzanines and other similar areas less than or equal to 200 gross square feet that do not contain a kitchen or a bathroom that allows for a ship's ladder to be an element of the means of egress.

children.body:
Handrail height, measured vertically from the sloped plane adjoining the tread nosing, or finish surface of ramp slope, shall be not less than 34 inches (864 mm) and not more than 38 inches (965 mm).

Exceptions:
  1. The use of a volute, turnout or starting easing shall be allowed over the lowest tread.
  2. Where handrail fittings or bendings are used to provide continuous transition between flights, transitions at winder treads, the transition from handrail to guard, or used at the start of a flight, the handrail height at the fittings or bendings shall be permitted to exceed 38 inches (965 mm).

diagrams.title: Handrail Height
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A handrail is required on at least one side of all flights of stairs exceeding 3 risers. Handrail height along flights of stairs is measured from the imaginary plane or planes defined by the stairway's tread nosing. The code calls for handrails to be from 34 to 38 inches in height. Though not specifically noted in the code, handrail height should be consistent along each flight of stairs. The code allows for the rail height to exceed 38" at continuous transitions, typically called "goosenecks", that take place at between flights of stairs, winder treads, and where the handrail transitions from a stair handrail to a guard. Over the lowest tread, the code also allows for the handrail height to be lower than 34" or taller than 38" for a volute, turnout or starting easing.

children.body:
Handrails shall not project more than 41/2 inches (114 mm) on either side of the stairway.
Exception: Where nosings of landings, floors or passing flights project into the stairway reducing the clearance at passing handrails, handrails shall project not more than 61/2 inches (165 mm) into the stairway, provided that the stair width and handrail clearance are not reduced to less than that required.
Handrails adjacent to a wall shall have a space of not less than 11/2 inches (38 mm) between the wall and the handrails.

Handrails shall be continuous for the full length of the flight, from a point directly above the top riser of the flight to a point directly above the lowest riser of the flight. Handrail ends shall be returned toward a wall, guard walking surface continuous to itself, or terminate to a post.

Exceptions:
  1. Handrail continuity shall be permitted to be interrupted by a newel post at a turn in a flight with winders, at a landing, or over the lowest tread.
  2. A volute, turnout or starting easing shall be allowed to terminate over the lowest tread and over the top landing.

diagrams.title: Handrail Continuity - Exception

Firstly, a continuous handrail maximizes safety by providing continuous support for individuals navigating staircases and ramps, reducing the risk of slips and falls. This is especially beneficial for individuals who may have mobility issues, such as older adults or individuals with certain disabilities. Newel posts at a turn in the flight with winders, at landings or over the lowest tread are permitted to interrupt the continuity of the handrail. A volute, turnout or starting easing shall be permitted to terminate over the lowest tread as well.
